verses.text: When Jesus had finished all these sayings, he said to his disciples,
verses.comment: Jesus speaks after concluding the previous teachings, transitioning to his final days.

verses.text: "You know that after two days the Passover is coming, and the Son of Man will be handed over to be crucified."
verses.comment: Jesus explicitly predicts his crucifixion at Passover. The timing links his death with the sacrificial lamb (Ex. 12:1-14), underlining a deep fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy and high christology—Jesus himself as the true Passover Lamb (cf. 1 Cor. 5:7).

verses.text: Then the chief priests and the elders of the people gathered in the court of the high priest, who was called Caiaphas,
verses.comment: The religious leaders plan Jesus' arrest. The council's authority underscores the drama surrounding Jesus.

verses.text: and conspired together to seize Jesus by stealth and kill him.
verses.comment: Their secret plotting fulfills Psalm 2:2—the rulers set themselves against the Lord's Anointed. This shows God works even through opposition.

verses.text: But they said, "Not during the feast, so that there will not be a riot among the people."
verses.comment: The leaders fear the crowds, revealing the popularity of Jesus. Yet, God's plan overrides theirs, as the arrest happens during the feast.

verses.text: Now when Jesus was in Bethany, in the house of Simon the leper,
verses.comment: Bethany is just outside Jerusalem, hosting events with great symbolic meaning.

verses.text: a woman came to him with an alabaster jar of very expensive ointment, and she poured it on his head as he reclined at the table.
verses.comment: The anointing anticipates Jesus' burial and reflects an act of deep devotion, symbolizing the outpouring of grace.

verses.text: But when the disciples saw it, they were indignant, saying, "Why this waste?"
verses.comment: The disciples' rebuke shows they fail to grasp the spiritual meaning behind the woman's action.

verses.text: "For this perfume could have been sold for much, and given to the poor."
verses.comment: The issue raised is between charity and ritual devotion—Jesus uses this to reveal a higher purpose.

verses.text: But Jesus, aware of this, said to them, "Why do you trouble the woman? For she has done a beautiful thing to me."
verses.comment: Jesus affirms acts of love and worship toward him, signaling his divine worthiness.

verses.text: "For you always have the poor with you, but you will not always have me."
verses.comment: See Deuteronomy 15:11—indicates Jesus’ unique messianic presence demands special honor.

verses.text: "For in pouring this ointment on my body, she did it to prepare me for burial."
verses.comment: Even in devotion, Christ’s death is at the center—this act is a prophetic witness.

verses.text: "Truly, I say to you, wherever this gospel is proclaimed in the whole world, what she has done will also be told in memory of her."
verses.comment: Preserving the woman’s act in the gospel tradition reflects the Church’s value on memorial acts and veneration.

verses.text: Then one of the twelve, who was called Judas Iscariot, went to the chief priests
verses.comment: Judas' betrayal is another step in salvation history, foreseen in the Psalms (Ps. 41:9).

verses.text: and said, "What will you give me if I deliver Him to you?" And they counted out thirty pieces of silver for him.
verses.comment: The thirty pieces of silver fulfill Zechariah 11:12, highlighting Jesus as the shepherd rejected by his people.

verses.text: And from that moment he sought an opportunity to betray him.
verses.comment: Judas becomes an agent in Christ’s passion, but God uses even betrayal for the greater work of redemption.

verses.text: Now on the first day of Unleavened Bread, the disciples came to Jesus, saying, "Where do you want us to prepare for you to eat the Passover?"
verses.comment: Connection to the ancient Passover points to Jesus as the true fulfillment of the old covenant feast.

verses.text: He said, "Go into the city to a certain man and say to him, 'The Teacher says, My time is at hand; I will keep the Passover at your house with my disciples.'"
verses.comment: "My time"—a reference to his impending Passion, manifestly under his sovereign control.

verses.text: And the disciples did as Jesus had directed them, and they prepared the Passover.
verses.comment: Their obedience shows trust in Jesus' divine foreknowledge and mission.

verses.text: When evening came, he was reclining at the table with the twelve.
verses.comment: Reclining at table reflects the Passover feast tradition, loaded with messianic symbolism.

verses.text: And as they were eating, he said, "Truly, I say to you, one of you will betray me."
verses.comment: The prophecy of betrayal is a fulfillment of Psalm 41:9, showing Jesus' self-knowledge as the Messiah.

verses.text: And they were very sorrowful and began to say to him one after another, "Is it I, Lord?"
verses.comment: The word "Lord" here shows their recognition of Jesus’ unique authority.

verses.text: He answered, "He who has dipped his hand in the dish with me will betray me."
verses.comment: Shared dish signals intimacy; the betrayal is especially grievous because it comes from one close.

verses.text: "The Son of Man goes as it is written about Him, but woe to that man by whom the Son of Man is betrayed! It would have been better for that man if he had not been born."
verses.comment: Jesus affirms the divine plan but underlines human accountability. Prophecies like Psalm 22 and Daniel 9 are fulfilled here.

verses.text: Judas, who betrayed Him, answered, "Is it I, Rabbi?" He said to him, "You have said it."
verses.comment: Judas calls Jesus 'Rabbi,' while the others say 'Lord', hinting at lack of true faith.

verses.text: Now as they were eating, Jesus took bread, and after blessing it, he broke it and gave it to the disciples, and said, "Take, eat; this is my body."
verses.comment: Jesus institutes the Eucharist, instituting the ongoing memorial and participation in his sacrificial body. The literal sense is reinforced by John 6:51-56—spiritual food that truly nourishes.

verses.text: And he took a cup, and when he had given thanks, he gave it to them, saying, "Drink of it, all of you,"
verses.comment: Participation in the cup symbolizes accepting the new covenant by sharing in Christ’s blood.

verses.text: "for this is my blood of the covenant, which is poured out for many for the forgiveness of sins."
verses.comment: Direct reference to Exodus 24:8 and Jeremiah 31:31-34. Christ’s blood is sacrificial and redemptive in a real sense, not merely symbolic—echoed in the Church’s teaching on real presence and the sacrament’s efficacy.

verses.text: "I tell you, I will not drink again of this fruit of the vine until that day when I drink it new with you in my Father’s kingdom."
verses.comment: A promise of the final Messianic banquet, fulfilled in the Church's eschatological hope.

verses.text: And when they had sung a hymn, they went out to the Mount of Olives.
verses.comment: The hymn would likely be from the Hallel psalms (Ps. 113–118), traditionally sung at Passover.

verses.text: Then Jesus said to them, "You will all fall away because of me this night. For it is written, 'I will strike the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock will be scattered.'"
verses.comment: Direct fulfillment of Zechariah 13:7. Christ is the Shepherd, and his passion foretold in prophecy.

verses.text: "But after I am raised up, I will go before you to Galilee."
verses.comment: Jesus predicts his resurrection and continued leadership of the apostles.

verses.text: Peter answered him, "Though they all fall away because of you, I will never fall away."
verses.comment: Peter’s confidence reveals his sincere love but lack of awareness of human weakness.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, "Truly, I say to you, this very night, before the rooster crows, you will deny me three times."
verses.comment: Jesus’ supernatural foreknowledge affirms his divinity and Peter’s frailty.

verses.text: Peter said to him, "Even if I must die with you, I will not deny you." And all the disciples said the same.
verses.comment: The disciples’ resolve foreshadows later failures but also the grace that will restore them.

verses.text: Then Jesus went with them to a place called Gethsemane, and he said to his disciples, "Sit here, while I go over there and pray."
verses.comment: Jesus’ prayer reveals his true humanity wrestling with the cup of suffering.

verses.text: And taking with him Peter and the two sons of Zebedee, he began to be sorrowful and deeply troubled.
verses.comment: Peter, James, and John are Jesus’ inner circle, privileged witnesses to his agony.

verses.text: Then he said to them, "My soul is very sorrowful, even to death; remain here, and watch with me."
verses.comment: Jesus fulfills the lament psalms in his anguish, standing in for all humanity.

verses.text: And going a little further, he fell on his face and prayed, saying, "My Father, if it is possible, let this cup pass from me; nevertheless, not as I will, but as you will."
verses.comment: Jesus’ submission models perfect filial obedience—"not my will but yours." The cup is a metaphor for wrath and sacrifice (Isa. 51:17; Jer. 25:15).

verses.text: And he came to the disciples and found them sleeping. And he said to Peter, "So, could you not watch with me one hour?"
verses.comment: The failure to keep watch embodies the weakness of the flesh and the need for constant prayer.

verses.text: "Watch and pray that you may not enter into temptation. The spirit is indeed willing, but the flesh is weak."
verses.comment: This verse is foundational for Christian spiritual life, highlighting the need for continuous prayer and vigilance.

verses.text: Again, for the second time, he went away and prayed, "My Father, if this cannot pass unless I drink it, your will be done."
verses.comment: Jesus’ human will remains perfectly united and obedient to the Father’s plan.

verses.text: And again he came and found them sleeping, for their eyes were heavy.
verses.comment: The disciples' frailty is repeatedly highlighted.

verses.text: So, leaving them again, he went away and prayed for the third time, saying the same words once more.
verses.comment: The triple prayer echoes the persistence in the Lord’s pattern of prayer.

verses.text: Then he came to the disciples and said to them, "Sleep and take your rest later on. See, the hour is at hand, and the Son of Man is betrayed into the hands of sinners."
verses.comment: Now the time of suffering has arrived, fulfilling the predicted ‘hour’ (John 12:23).

verses.text: "Rise, let us be going; see, my betrayer is at hand."
verses.comment: Jesus goes forth willingly to his Passion.

verses.text: While he was still speaking, Judas came, one of the twelve, and with him a great crowd with swords and clubs, from the chief priests and elders of the people.
verses.comment: The solemnity of the betrayal stressed by the identification of Judas as 'one of the twelve.'

verses.text: Now the betrayer had given them a sign, saying, "The one I will kiss is the man; seize him."
verses.comment: The act of a kiss, an intimate gesture, increases the bitterness of the betrayal.

verses.text: And immediately he went up to Jesus and said, "Greetings, Rabbi!" and kissed him.
verses.comment: Judas’ address 'Rabbi' again distinguishes him from the true confessors of Jesus as Lord and underlines his tragic choice.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, "Friend, do what you came for." Then they came up and laid hands on Jesus and seized him.
verses.comment: Jesus’ use of ‘friend’ is both compassionate and sorrowful—divine mercy in the face of betrayal.

verses.text: And behold, one of those who were with Jesus stretched out his hand and drew his sword, and struck the servant of the high priest and cut off his ear.
verses.comment: John identifies the swordsman as Peter and the servant as Malchus. Highlights the tendency to rely on human power rather than God’s will.

verses.text: Then Jesus said to him, "Put your sword back into its place. For all who take the sword will perish by the sword."
verses.comment: Jesus opposes violent retaliation, echoing a principle seen in Genesis 9:6 and reinforcing peace.

verses.text: "Do you think that I cannot appeal to my Father, and he will at once send me more than twelve legions of angels?"
verses.comment: Jesus’ divine authority is emphasized—he willingly submits, not out of weakness.

verses.text: "But how then would the Scriptures be fulfilled, that it must be so?"
verses.comment: The necessity of Christ’s suffering is grounded in prophecy—especially Isaiah 53.

verses.text: At that hour Jesus said to the crowds, "Have you come out as against a robber, with swords and clubs to capture me? Every day I sat in the temple teaching, and you did not seize me."
verses.comment: The secrecy of their actions contrasts with Jesus’ openness in ministry, manifesting their unjust motives.

verses.text: But all this has taken place that the Scriptures of the prophets might be fulfilled." Then all the disciples left him and fled.
verses.comment: The Scriptures are fulfilled even as the disciples fall away, emphasizing God’s ultimate sovereignty.

verses.text: Then those who had seized Jesus led him to Caiaphas the high priest, where the scribes and the elders had gathered.
verses.comment: Jesus is delivered to the religious authorities for judgment.

verses.text: And Peter followed him at a distance, as far as the courtyard of the high priest, and going inside he sat with the guards to see the outcome.
verses.comment: Peter’s following at a distance reflects both loyalty and fear, anticipating his impending denial.

verses.text: Now the chief priests and the whole council were seeking false testimony against Jesus so that they might put him to death,
verses.comment: Their use of false witnesses starkly contrasts with Jesus’ innocence.

verses.text: but they found none, though many false witnesses came forward. At last, two came forward
verses.comment: By law, two witnesses are needed (Deut. 19:15), though their testimony is spurious.

verses.text: and said, "This man said, 'I am able to destroy the temple of God, and to build it in three days.'"
verses.comment: They misunderstand Jesus’ words about his resurrection as referring to the physical temple. His body is the true Temple (John 2:19-21).

verses.text: And the high priest stood up and said, "Have you no answer to make? What is it that these men testify against you?"
verses.comment: The high priest presses for self-incrimination.

verses.text: But Jesus remained silent. And the high priest said to him, "I adjure you by the living God, tell us if you are the Christ, the Son of God."
verses.comment: Jesus’ silence fulfills Isaiah 53:7. The title “Son of God” points to Jesus’ unique divine status (see also Ps. 2:7).

verses.text: Jesus said to him, "You have said so. But I tell you, from now on you will see the Son of Man seated at the right hand of Power and coming on the clouds of heaven."
verses.comment: Here Jesus claims the messianic and divine titles of Psalm 110:1 and Daniel 7:13—his high christology is unmistakable. The 'right hand of Power' implies equality with God.

verses.text: Then the high priest tore his robes and said, "He has uttered blasphemy! What further witnesses do we need? You have now heard his blasphemy."
verses.comment: The high priest understands Jesus’ words as a direct claim to divinity (Lev. 24:16), which was punishable by death in Jewish law.

verses.text: "What is your judgment?" They answered, "He deserves death."
verses.comment: The Sanhedrin passes judgment, fulfilling the pattern of the righteous sufferer.

verses.text: Then they spit in his face and struck him; and some slapped him,
verses.comment: Isaiah 50:6 prophesies the suffering of the Servant. Jesus fulfills the prophecy.

verses.text: saying, "Prophesy to us, you Christ! Who is it that struck you?"
verses.comment: The mockery is paradoxical; Jesus is the true Prophet foretold in Deut. 18:15.

verses.text: Now Peter was sitting outside in the courtyard, and a servant girl came up to him and said, "You also were with Jesus the Galilean."
verses.comment: Peter’s test of faith begins here, with pressure from even the humble.

verses.text: But he denied it before them all, saying, "I do not know what you mean."
verses.comment: Peter, in fear, denies Jesus, fulfilling his earlier prediction.

verses.text: And when he went out to the entrance, another servant girl saw him, and she said to the bystanders, "This man was with Jesus of Nazareth."
verses.comment: The pressure on Peter intensifies.

verses.text: And he again denied it with an oath: "I do not know the man."
verses.comment: Peter swears an oath, increasing the level of denial.

verses.text: After a little while the bystanders came up and said to Peter, "Certainly you also are one of them, for your accent betrays you."
verses.comment: Peter’s Galilean accent gives him away among those in Jerusalem.

verses.text: Then he began to curse and to swear, "I do not know the man." And immediately the rooster crowed.
verses.comment: Peter's third denial, with cursing, reveals the fullness of human frailty. The crowing rooster marks the fulfillment of Jesus' prophecy.

verses.text: And Peter remembered the word Jesus had said, "Before the rooster crows, you will deny me three times." And he went out and wept bitterly.
verses.comment: Peter’s bitter weeping displays heartfelt repentance, preparing him for restoration as a chief shepherd (see John 21:15-17).
